title: ATC unveils Birdcage rival to keep punters in Sydney
text:
“We don’t actually like to make comparisons to Melbourne, but here you can actually see the horses.”

Premium hospitality spaces

Black says The Estate concept was developed earlier this year, after the club put its hospitality packages on sale for the Everest race meeting, to be held on October 19.

“Within two weeks, everything we had in our existing inventory was all but sold out,” Black says.

We are actually 40 per cent ahead of last year’s results in terms of hospitality sales. — Corina Black, executive general manager of commercial operations, ATC

The race, which was the brainchild of Racing NSW boss Peter V’Landys, is one of the richest in the world, with total prizemoney of $13 million.

The new enclosure, developed with event group Harry the Hirer, offers a mix of private areas and shared spaces. In the ultra-premium Manor marquee, guest will dine on a menu prepared by celebrity chef Guillaume Brahimi.

The ATC’s big partners, including drinks giant Lion, gaming group Tabcorp and casino giant The Star Entertainment Group, will entertain clients in the new complex. And despite the apparent fragility of the economy, The Estate has been close to sold out for every meeting at Randwick this spring.

Advertisement

“We are actually 40 per cent ahead of last year’s results in terms of hospitality sales,” Black says.

She believes a big part of the attraction for corporate clients is racing’s gender neutral appeal; time-poor guests now want to be able to bring partners if they’re giving up a day of their weekend.

And corporate clients want a return on their investment. The regular breaks between races – nine half times, as Black likes to say – provide plenty of opportunities to talk shop.

“What I hear from clients all the time is if they are going to invest that they need to get value out of it. Having the ability to hold your customer for that many hours and really get value is so important,” Black says.

The strong sales for The Estates have convinced the ATC to develop the concept further, with Black already investigating a more permanent structure.

“We’d love to have a double-storey facility to really capitalise on the view.”
description: Sydney's Australian Turf Club is taking aim at one of Flemington’s sacred sites: the Birdcage enclosure.
